attributes.title: Psychological Distance
attributes.description: Project examining the impact of psychological distance on children's socio-cognitive skills and reasoning

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value:
For the future saving action task, we may additionally consider children’s behaviors during the time they are waiting to receive the dinosaur sheet. For instance, we may consider the kinds of inhibition strategies that children use (e.g., touching the stickers vs. looking away from them; searching for distractions; self-soothing or regulating behaviors, etc.). One possibility is that children who use these strategies are more successful compared to those who do not. 


Note: data collection is under-way, but no data has been analyzed or looked at.

sample.value: 108 children will be tested, with an even number of children assigned to each of three conditions: self, in-group and out-group (36 participants per condition).

analyses.value:
Descriptive statistics: We will compare the relative frequencies and means of children’s responses across age and condition using logistic and linear regression models. We will additionally examine whether these frequencies and means differ by gender. We do not have any predictions with respect to gender; assuming no gender differences, we will not further consider this as a covariate. 

Effect of condition on performance: To test our main hypothesis about the impact of distance on children’s behavior, we will test for condition differences across the six tasks (sharing predict, saving predict, free-will, sharing action, saving action, DCCS). We will use binomial logistic and linear regression models with children’s performance on each of these tasks as the respective outcome, and condition as a predictor. We will also include age (in months) as a covariate. We will additionally examine whether the interaction between condition and age explains additional variance (i.e., whether the impact of distance changes with age). To compare differences across conditions, we will use R’s emmeans package to compare performance between pairs of conditions (i.e., self versus in-group; self versus out-group; in-group versus out-group). Our predictions for individual tasks follow the predictions outlined above. 

Effect of perceived distance/likeability (etc.) on performance: We will additionally examine whether participants’ judgments of the character they pretended to be have an impact on individual children’s behavior. Specifically, we will examine whether children’s responses to the distance measures (concentric circles, sharing, character evaluations) predict their performance on the socio-cognitive tasks. We will examine this relation using logistic and linear regression models with performance on the socio-cognitive tasks as the outcome variable and character evaluation, condition and age as predictors (additionally examining whether the interactions between these variables explain additional variance). Here, our predictions follow those outlined in Section 1. 

Inter-task correlations: We will examine whether children’s behavior on the different socio-cognitive tasks correlate with one another, independent of age. We will examine whether children’s responses to the different distance measures correlate with one another (e.g., does perceived distance from the character predict whether children share with the character). 

Prediction-Action differences: We will compute difference scores between children’s predictions and actions for sharing and future saving. We will examine whether this prediction-action difference changes with age and/or is predicted by condition. We expect that this difference will lessen with age, as children may become more aware of their own actions. Additionally, this difference may be greatest in the self condition, given that predicting someone else’s behavior may allow children to think more abstractly. 

We will also consider the correlation between children’s predictions and actions (for sharing and saving), and whether the relation between children’s predictions and actions differs as a function of condition. One possibility is that distance (particularly the out-group condition) may lead children to more accurately predict behavior. In contrast, in the self condition (and perhaps also the in-group condition), children may be overly optimistic about their behaviors (therefore predicting better performance than their actual performance).

outliers.value: Children who fail to answer any questions, and children who fail to finish the experiment, will be excluded from the data. Children who do not correctly answer all trials on the pre-switch of the DCCS will be excluded from analyses for the DCCS. Likewise, children who do not complete one of the measures (but do complete other measures) will be excluded from analyses including that measure but not others.

dependent.value:
All children will respond to six tasks: three prediction tasks and three action tasks. Children will always complete the prediction tasks first. Within each block, the three tasks will be presented in a counterbalanced order. For the prediction tasks, children are asked to predict how they, an in-group child, or an out-group child (between-subjects) will behave. For the action tasks, children are asked to complete three tasks while being themselves, pretending to be an in-group child, or pretending to be an out-group child (between-subjects). Finally, children in the in-group and out-group conditions will complete a series of tasks examining their perceptions of the in-group and out-group characters (distance measures). 

Prediction tasks (presented in counterbalanced order):
Free-will: Children will be presented with two desirable items (an iPad and an ice cream sundae). For each item, children will be asked whether they (or the person they are pretending to be) have to play with/eat the item, or whether they can choose not to play with/eat the item. Responses will be scored in a binary manner: “choose not to”=1 or “have to”=0.
Sharing prediction: Children will be told that they will later complete a sharing game. Children will be  asked to predict how they (or the child they are pretending to be) will share resources between themselves and another child on this task. Children are presented with cards that show different resource distributions ranging from sharing 0-5 stickers on a zero-sum basis between themselves and the other child (e.g., 0-5, 1-4, 2-3, etc.). Responses will be coded as the number of stickers children predict sharing with another child. 
Saving prediction: Children will be told that they (or the child they are pretending to be) will later receive a sheet of dinosaur stickers and will have the option to immediately put their stickers on a small, blank sheet of paper, or to save their stickers and wait until the experimenter gets a “really cool dinosaur paper” from another room. Children will be asked to predict whether they will save “just one of the stickers, a few of the stickers, most of the stickers, or all of the stickers” to put onto the dinosaur scene. These responses will be numerically coded: “just one of the stickers”=1, “a few stickers”=2, “most of the stickers”=3, “all of the stickers”=4. 

Action tasks (counterbalanced):
Sharing action: Five stickers will be placed on the table in front of the child. Children will be asked to decide how many stickers to keep for themselves and how many stickers to give to another child who they are told will participate later. Responses will be scored from 0-5, indicating the number of stickers children share with the other kid. 
Saving action: Children will be given a sheet of dinosaur stickers and a small, blank piece of paper (¼ of a sheet). They will be told they can put the stickers on the blank paper, or they can save their stickers and wait until the experimenter gets a “really cool dinosaur paper” for the stickers from another room. Then, the experimenter will leave for one minute to retrieve the dinosaur paper. The number of stickers that children put on the blank paper will be recorded. 
Executive Functioning: The Dimensional Change Card Sort (DCCS) will be used to assess executive functioning. Children will be told that it’s time to play a card game. Instructions will follow Zelazo (2006). All children will complete the original version. Children who pass this version (at least 5 of 6 cards sorted correctly) will complete the border trials. Children’s performance will be scored as the number of correct trials during the pre-switch, post-switch, and border trials. Performance will additionally be coded as a binary variable (pass/fail) for post-switch and border trials. Passing post-switch=at least 4/6 correct; passing border trial = at least 9/12 correct (following Zelazo, 2006). 

Distance measures
Concentric circles: Children will be given a piece of paper with five concentric circles and a stick figure in the middle of the center-most circle. Children will be told that they are the stick figure in the middle, and things similar to them go close to them in the inner circles, and things different from them go further away in the outer circles. Then, children will be asked to draw where the in-group or out-group child they were pretending to be should go. Children's responses will be coded as the marked distance from the center of the circle (0-5, with high number = more distant). Additionally, the type of drawing done will be recorded using the following categories: a shape (e.g., a line, another circle, a scribble) or a person (e.g., a stick figure or drawing of a face or person). 
Sharing: Five stickers will be placed in front of the child, and they will be asked how many stickers they want to keep for themselves, and how many they want to give to the child they were pretending to be (stickers for themselves will be placed in front of them, and stickers for Julia(n) or Zulia(n) will be placed in a cup). Responses will be scored with a discrete numerical value, 0-5, indicating the number of stickers they shared with the other kid on a zero-sum basis. 
Character evaluations: Children will be asked several questions about Julia(n) or Zulia(n) regarding how nice/smart/strong they are, as well as how much knowledge they have. Children will be asked to provide responses using a scale comprising three circles that increase in size (small circle = “not very,”  medium circle = “a little,” large circle = “very” or “a lot.” Responses will be coded as: “not” = 1, “a little” = 2, and “very” / “a lot”=3. We will examine the relation between these judgments. If these items cluster together (Cronbach’s alpha), we will consider collapsing responses into one evaluation score (e.g., the average of responses). 
Drawing: Children will be asked to draw a picture of themselves and of Julia(n) or Zulia(n). Drawings will be coded along a number of dimensions: similarity between self and other drawing, size differences between self and other, distance between the two characters on the page, and emotions depicted in self and other.

conditions.value: Participants will be assigned to one of three conditions, between subjects: self, in-group, or out-group. Children will be assigned to these conditions such that children are evenly distributed across conditions by age (4-, 5-, and 6-year-olds) and gender. Within condition, children will be assigned to one of six counterbalancing versions (Version 1-Version 6).

hypothesis.value:
This study examines the influence of psychological distancing on 4-6 year olds’ performance on a range of socio-cognitive tasks. Past work has explored the impact of psychological distancing on children’s executive functioning by assigning them to complete tasks either as themselves or while pretending to be a fictional character (e.g., White & Carlson, 2016; White, Prager, Schaefer, Kross, Duckworth, & Carlson, 2017). Other research has explored the impact of psychological distancing on children’s future thinking by assigning children to answer questions about themselves or about a similar or dissimilar peer (Lee & Atance, 2016). Together, this work leaves open questions about the range of tasks that psychological distancing may impact, as well as whether psychological distance differentially affects children’s predictions versus actions. Moreover, past research raises questions about the extent to which children benefit from distance specifically, or by other factors that may at times accompany distance, such as the perceived ability (i.e., competence) of another person and the ease of pretending to be this person.  

In the present study, psychological distance will be operationalized in the social domain (i.e., social distance). Participants will complete a battery of socio-cognitive tasks. Between-subjects, participants will be assigned to a Self condition in which children make predictions about their own behavior and act as themselves; an “In-group” (someone who lives near the child and speaks their same language) condition in which children make predictions about an in-group child’s behavior and pretend to be an in-group child); or an “Out-group” (someone who lives far away from the child and speaks a different language). condition in which children make predictions about an out-group child’s behavior and pretend to be an out-group child. All children will complete six tasks. Three tasks will involve predicting future behavior. The other three tasks will involve children actually completing the tasks. 

The main questions regard the effect of distance (self, in-group, out-group) on performance across the various tasks assessing free-will beliefs, sharing, future saving, and executive functioning. Additional questions regard whether this effect differs depending on if children are predicting behavior or acting/pretending. Critically, the included tasks show improved performance over the tested age range and have been shown to exhibit self-other differences. There are two central hypotheses being considered: 

H1: Increased psychological distance will improve task performance: the more distant children are from their own perspective (self), the greater their performance will be on the various tasks (i.e., greater perceived free will; greater saving for the future; increased prosociality; increased executive functioning). Thus, within age groups, children in the out-group condition will perform better than children in the in-group condition, who will perform better than children in the self-condition. This prediction is general to tasks involving prediction and tasks involving pretending.  

H2: The impact of psychological distance depends on factors such as perceived competence or liking. If someone more similar is perceived as more competent or is liked more, then children in the in-group condition, but not children in the out-group condition, may show improved performance across both predictions and actions. 

H3: The impact of psychological distance on task performance will depend on ease of pretense. If it is easier for children to pretend to be someone more similar to them, then children may show improved performance in the in-group condition but not the out-group condition. Because this latter prediction is specific to pretense, it should not affect predictions. Thus, one possibility is that children will show improved predictions in both the in-group and out-group condition, but only show improved action in the in-group condition. 

In addition to effects of the psychological distancing condition, a secondary aim of this study is to examine the relation between the included socio-cognitive tasks. Past work demonstrates self-other differences on all of these tasks, suggesting children’s behaviors across these tasks may be related. Therefore, we predict there may be a positive correlation between children’s behaviors on free-will, sharing, future thinking, and executive functioning, independent of age.

attributes.title: Attention and Priming in video games

q1.value: Attention and priming of video game features

q3.value: This pre-registration is for a large scale online study which investigates how attentional focus on game features moderates priming in video games. In the study participants will play a video game and then be tested as to whether they are primed by the contents of the game. To manipulate attentional selection participants will play one of two versions of the game Two Dots. Both games contain coloured dots which contain images. In the Match Colours game version participants need to match dots of the same colour and the images are irrelevant to the game. This should create attentional selection on to the colours of the dots and away from the images. In the Match Images game version participants need to match dots with the same image and the dot colours are irrelevant to the game. This should create attentional selection away from the colours and onto the images.

q4.value:
H1: There will be a significant difference in the amount participants are primed by the images when they play a game which focuses their attention on the images compared to a game which focuses attention away from the images. 
H2: In the Match Images game participants will be significantly faster to match images they have previously been shown than images they have not been shown. This will indicate positive priming of the images. 
H3: In the Match Colours game participants will be significantly slower to match images they had previously been shown in the game than images they have not been shown. This will indicate negative priming of the images.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The experiment will have a 2 (game variant) x 2 (image type) mixed design. Participants will play either the Match Colours game or the Match Images game. Each participant will then undertake a "priming quiz" which tests them for their reaction times to both images that were shown during the game and also to images that were not shown during the game.
Example screens from each game are attached, as are example priming quiz screens and all the images which are used in both the games and priming quiz

q9.value: There are 8 categories of images, each with 4 images in them. During each game, players are show 4 categories of image and all the images in that category. The categories they are shown is randomised for each player. In the priming test they are tested on one random image from each category they have seen and one random image from each category they have not been shown. The priming quiz also has 3 practice questions which use 6 new images which are not in any of the other 8 categories. Random numbers will be generated by a Linear congruential generator algorithm built into the experimental code which follows best practice to maximise randomness of the output.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited using the Prolific (https://www.prolific.co/) online experimental platform and paid £1.75 for performing the study which will take them less than 10 minutes. Participants must be at least 18 years old and speakers of English. The study takes the form of a interactive web page which participants access through a browser on a desktop or laptop computer but not a tablet or phone.

q13.value: We set our initial sample size of 200 valid participants. As this is a between-participants study with 2 conditions there will be 100 participants per condition.

q14.value: To determine the number of participants in our experiment we considered previous studies, performed a pilot study and power calculations. Wood and Simons (2019) used 100 participants per condition for their large scale replication of attention and priming experiment. As we have two conditions this would mean 200 participants. Zendle et al (2018) investigated negative priming in games and found an effect size (partial eta squared) of  0.043. We performed a pilot study (n=28) of this study and found an effect size (partial eta squared) of 0.1. Power calculations performed using the R pwr package show that an effect size of 0.043 would need around 180 participants for a power of 0.80. An effect size of 0.1 would need around 80.

q15.value: We will collect 210 participants and discard any not fitting the exclusion criteria. question.value: The only manipulated variable will be the game version that participants play; either the Match Colours game or the Match Images game.

We will measure two variables for the experimental analysis: reaction time to classify an image participants have previously been shown and reaction time to an image they have not previously been shown. We will also collect, the game level participants reach, whether they are colour blind and whether they see any bugs in the software which will be used to screen invalid participants.
Reaction time to previously shown images: Participants will be asked to match an image that they have previously seen in the game to one of two other images. They will be asked to do this four times. As is commonly done in priming studies such as Zendle (2018) we will take the natural logarithm of each time and then measure the mean value of the 4 trials. 
Reaction time to images not previously shown: Participants will be asked to match an image that they have NOT previously seen in the game to one of two other images. They will be asked to do this four times. As above we will take the natural logarithm of each time and record the mean value of 4 trials. 

Game level: Participants will all play the game for 5 minutes. We will measure the level of the game that they got to. 
Colour blindness: We will ask players if they have any type of colour blindness and exclude all those who answer yes as the Match Colours game requires players to be able to identify colours. 
Bugs in the experiment software: We will ask players if they experienced any bugs or other technical issues with the experiment software and exclude any experiencing bugs as this could be a confound on the data.

Participants reaction time to images they have and haven't previously seen will be recorded. They will perform the reaction time task 4 times for both shown and not shown images. We will take the natural logarithm of each time and record the mean value of 4 trials for both shown and not shown images.

H1: We will use a 2 x 2 mixed-design ANOVA to see if there is a significant interaction between the game condition and whether the images were shown in the game

H2 and H3: We will use repeated measures ANOVAs to test for simple main effects of priming within conditions. For H2 in the Match Images game we expect shown images to be faster than not shown images (showing positive priming). For H3 in the Match Colours game we expect shown images to be slower than not shown images (showing negative priming)

registration_responses.q1: Attention and priming of video game features
registration_responses.q3: This pre-registration is for a large scale online study which investigates how attentional focus on game features moderates priming in video games. In the study participants will play a video game and then be tested as to whether they are primed by the contents of the game. To manipulate attentional selection participants will play one of two versions of the game Two Dots. Both games contain coloured dots which contain images. In the Match Colours game version participants need to match dots of the same colour and the images are irrelevant to the game. This should create attentional selection on to the colours of the dots and away from the images. In the Match Images game version participants need to match dots with the same image and the dot colours are irrelevant to the game. This should create attentional selection away from the colours and onto the images.
registration_responses.q4:
H1: There will be a significant difference in the amount participants are primed by the images when they play a game which focuses their attention on the images compared to a game which focuses attention away from the images. 
H2: In the Match Images game participants will be significantly faster to match images they have previously been shown than images they have not been shown. This will indicate positive priming of the images. 
H3: In the Match Colours game participants will be significantly slower to match images they had previously been shown in the game than images they have not been shown. This will indicate negative priming of the images.

q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: There are 8 categories of images, each with 4 images in them. During each game, players are show 4 categories of image and all the images in that category. The categories they are shown is randomised for each player. In the priming test they are tested on one random image from each category they have seen and one random image from each category they have not been shown. The priming quiz also has 3 practice questions which use 6 new images which are not in any of the other 8 categories. Random numbers will be generated by a Linear congruential generator algorithm built into the experimental code which follows best practice to maximise randomness of the output.

registration_responses.q13: We set our initial sample size of 200 valid participants. As this is a between-participants study with 2 conditions there will be 100 participants per condition.
registration_responses.q14: To determine the number of participants in our experiment we considered previous studies, performed a pilot study and power calculations. Wood and Simons (2019) used 100 participants per condition for their large scale replication of attention and priming experiment. As we have two conditions this would mean 200 participants. Zendle et al (2018) investigated negative priming in games and found an effect size (partial eta squared) of  0.043. We performed a pilot study (n=28) of this study and found an effect size (partial eta squared) of 0.1. Power calculations performed using the R pwr package show that an effect size of 0.043 would need around 180 participants for a power of 0.80. An effect size of 0.1 would need around 80.

q15.value: This study employs a survey experiment embedded in a nationally representative survey of Ukrainians to offer a systematic assessment of the effectiveness of – as well as the risk of backfire effects from – anti-corruption messaging.

q16.value: The primary hypotheses are: H1.1: Positively framed anti-corruption messages should decrease willingness to offer bribes. H1.2a: Negatively framed anti-corruption messages should decrease willingness to offer bribes (i.e., desired effect). H1.2b: Negatively framed anti-corruption messages should increase willingness to offer bribes (i.e., backfire effect). H2.1: Positively framed anti-corruption messages should increase willingness to participate in anti-corruption activism. H2.2a: Negatively framed anti-corruption messages should increase willingness to participate in anti-corruption activism (i.e., desired effect). H2.2b: Negatively framed anti-corruption messages should decrease willingness to participate in anti-corruption activism (i.e., backfire effect).

q17.value: This study will employ an information experiment embedded in a representative survey of adult Ukrainians. One third of the sample will be assigned randomly to a treatment group which will be shown an anti-corruption flyer with a positive message emphasizing that anti-corruption campaigns in Ukraine are beginning to show success (i.e., that levels of corruption are declining). Another third of the sample will be assigned to a second treatment group which will be shown an anti-corruption flyer with a negative message emphasizing that corruption is a growing problem that needs to be stopped. The final third of the sample will be assigned to a control group which will not be shown a flyer.

attributes.title: Acupuncture and manual therapy for rotator cuff tears: a protocol for systematic review  and meta analysis
attributes.description: The tears of rotator cuff is caused by the tears or aseptic inflammation of tendon tissue such as subscapular muscle, supraspinatus muscle, infraspinatus muscle, teres minor muscle, etc., which make up the rotator cuff. Managements of rotator cuff disease often include acupuncture and manual therapy, usually delivered together. The aim of this review is to assess the effectiveness and safety of such interventions in patients with pain and dysfunction caused by rotator cuff tears.

q1.value: Hongzhi Tang, Fei Luo, Huaying Fan, Li Huang, Shichuan Liao, Wenjing Yu, Yunbei Chen, Xuefei Qin, Jiao Chen

q2.value: Rotator cuff tears is one of the common musculoskeletal complaints, and significantly impacts a person’s health-related quality of life. Epidemiological studies have reported that 20% of people over 20 years old suffer from rotator cuff tears, while 25% of people over 50 years old suffer from rotator cuff tears, which is the main cause of shoulder joint pain and dysfunction and greatly affects patients’ work efficiency and quality of life. An epidemiological study in the United States reports that 4.5 million people are hospitalized every year for Rotator cuff tears. The rotator cuff is composed of supraspinatus muscle, infraspinatus muscle, subscapularis muscle and teres minor muscle. It starts from the shoulder rib and attaches around the humeral head, forming a sleeve like structure at the anatomical neck of the humeral head. The function of the rotator cuff is to support and stabilize the shoulder and humeral joint, maintain the sealing function of the shoulder joint cavity, maintain the synovial fluid to nourish the articular cartilage, and prevent the secondary osteoarthritis. The treatment principle of rotator cuff tears is to reduce pain and improve the function of shoulder joint. The most common actions taken at present to relieve the symptoms of rotator cuff tears include steroid injections, oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), physical therapy, exercise therapy, manual therapy, ultrasound therapy and acupuncture. In practice, people with rotator cuff tears seldom receive a single intervention in isolation. Acupuncture and manual therapy usually delivered together as components of a physical therapy intervention, are commonly used in the management of rotator cuff tears. Acupuncture is commonly used for musculoskeletal disorders, and it has been suggested as a meaningful nonsurgical intervention for managing shoulder pain and dysfunction. Manual therapy is also commonly used in the management of rotator cuff tears. Manual therapy includes any clinician-applied movement of the joints and other structures, for example mobilization (of which several types exist) or manipulation. The aims of both types of interventions are to improve function, promote healing, increase joint range, strengthen weakened muscles and correct imbalance in the stabilizing function of the rotator cuff. The mechanism of acupuncture treatment has not been fully elucidated. Some studies have pointed out that the mechanism of acupuncture and moxibustion treatment may be related to the local effect, which refers to the release of neuropeptide and other substances by stimulating the sensory nerve endings of skin and muscle tissue. The research shows that acupuncture can promote the release of β-endorphin and increase the concentration of 5-hydroxytryptamine in brain tissue, so as to reduce the sensitivity of tissue to pain and improve joint activity. Manual therapy can stimulate peripheral mechanoreceptors and inhibit nociceptors to reducing pain, and can enhance exchange between synovial ﬂuid and cartilage matrix to increasing joint mobility. Previous systematic reviews have not assessed acupuncture and manual therapy for rotator cuff tears together. Consequently, we decided to conduct a systematic review based on the best currently available evidence and methodology to evaluate whether acupuncture and manual therapy is effect and safety for pain and function of rotator cuff tears.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: 1.Types of studies We will include randomized controlled trials (RCTs) of acupuncture treatment for pain and dysfunction caused by rotator cuff tears. RCTs in English and Chinese will be included in the review. RCTs using single-blind, double-blind or open-label design will be included. For crossover trials, data are extracted from the first period only, to avoid potential carryover effects. 2. Types of participants Adult patients (aged ≥ 18 years) diagnosed with Rotator cuff tears will be included, with the symptoms of shoulder joint pain or dysfunction enrollment in the research. We will exclude trials that include any participants with a history of signiﬁcant trauma or systemic inﬂammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, hemiplegic shoulders, or pain in the shoulder region as part of a complex myofascial neck/shoulder/arm pain condition. 3. Types of interventions All randomized controlled comparisons of acupuncture or manual therapy versus placebo, no treatment, another active intervention will be included. Trials evaluating the primary or add-on effects of acupuncture and manual therapy, acupuncture alone, and manual therapy alone are eligible. Acupuncture will be considered only of it involves needle insertion at acupuncture points, pain points, or trigger points, and had to be described as acupuncture. We will exclude other methods of stimulating acupuncture points without needle insertion (such as laser stimulation or transcutaneous electrical stimulation). Eligible manual therapy interventions include mobilization, manipulation and massage. We will exclude studies that only compare different forms or methods of acupuncture (e.g. transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation) and compare acupuncture with any complementary and alternative therapies for which the efﬁcacy is not yet established (e.g. Chinese herbs).

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Two review authors (THZ and LF) will independently screen all abstracts identiﬁed from the literature search, then exclude those that are clearly irrelevant (e.g. studies focusing on other conditions, reviews, etc.). We will obtain full texts of all remaining references and the same two review authors will screen and exclude clearly irrelevant papers according to the selection criteria. We will resolve disagreements by discussion or with a third review author.

1.Primary outcomes  Pain intensity (measured by validated scales, such as the visual analogue scale (VAS) or numeric rating scale);  Shoulder function (measured by validated scales, such as the Constant-Murley score (CMS), Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) total scale, Dutch Shoulder Disability Questionnaire (SDQ-NL), Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) score, University of California-Los Angeles (UCLA) Shoulder rating scale, or the American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) rating scale). 2.Secondary outcomes  Health-related quality of life measured on validated scales such as Short-Form 36 (SF-36) Health Survey or EuroQol;  Patient global assessment of treatment outcomes, such as the Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC);  Adverse events;  Active range of motion of shoulder joint;  Proportion of patients who finally ended up receiving shoulder surgery.

We will use Rev Man software (Review Manager Version 5.3 for Windows, The Nordic Cochrane Centre, Copenhagen) to carry out statistical analysis. A random effects model will be used to calculate the pooled effect estimates, because substantial clinical heterogeneity is expected among the studies included in this review. If considerable heterogeneity (I2>75%) is observed, we will not meta-analyze the trials and will qualitatively synthesize the data.

q21.value: We will contact the authors in China via telephone, and authors from elsewhere via email to obtain missing data, if necessary. For all outcomes, we will carry out analyses, and both per-protocol (PP) analysis and intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis will be accepted. Attrition rates, for example dropouts, losses to follow up, and withdrawals, will be investigated. If the missing data is not accessible, we will exclude these articles and synthesis the rest of the included studies.

attributes.title: Safety and effectiveness of convalescent plasma or hyperimmune globulin for people with COVID-19: a rapid review

q1.value: Sarah J Valk, Vanessa Piechotta, Khai Li Chai, Erica M Wood, Abigail Lamikanra, Catherine Kimber, Zoe McQuilten, Ina Monsef, Carolyn Doree, Lise Estcourt, Susan J Brunskill, Nicole Skoetz

q2.value:
Description of the condition

The clinical syndrome coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a new, rapidly emerging zoonotic infectious disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) (WHO 2020). The current COVID-19 outbreak was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization on the 11th of March 2020, and has caused 1,696,588 cases and 105,952 deaths worldwide (dated: 12 April 2020) (WHO 2020a; WHO 2020b). Although there are similarities with historic coronavirus epidemics, with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and Middle Eastern respiratory syndrome (MERS) responsible for 813 and 858 deaths respectively, the scale and impact of the COVID-19 pandemic presents unprecedented challenges to health facilities and healthcare workers all over the world (WHO 2007; WHO 2019).

With a preliminary hospitalization rate of 12.3 patients per 100,000 population in the United States, COVID-19 has taken a toll on healthcare capacity, and especially on intensive care unit (ICU) capacity (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention 2020). Early reports of the case fatality rate suggest it ranges between of 0.7-4%, with higher rates also reported (WHO 2020; WHO 2020b). However, these numbers should be interpreted with great care due to the data pertaining to the early emergency response, which due to shortage of test kits has led to selective testing of patients with severe disease and underreporting of cases, and delays from confirmation of a case to death (Kim 2020). The median incubation period of SARS-CoV-2 was reported to be 5 days, with 97.5% of cases developing symptoms within 11.5 days of infection (Lauer 2020). Clinical signs and symptoms include fever (87.9%), dry cough (67.7%), fatigue (38.1%), sputum production (33.4%), shortness of breath (18.6%), sore throat (13.9%), headache (13.6%), myalgia or arthralgia (14.8%), chills (11.4%), nausea or vomiting (5.0%), nasal congestion (4.8%), diarrhea (3.7%), hemoptysis (0.9%) and conjunctival congestion (0.8%) (WHO 2020). Of the reported cases, 80% is estimated to have a mild or asymptomatic course of infection, and an estimated 5% of cases are admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), septic shock and/or multiple organ failure (Team 2020; WHO 2020). A risk factor for developing infection and progressing to severe disease is old age, with people aged >80 at highest risk of mortality. Other risk factors are hypertension, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, chronic respiratory disease, compromised immune status, cancer and obesity (Chen 2020; Huang 2020; Liang 2020; WHO 2020; Wu 2020).

SARS-CoV-2 is a positive-sense, single stranded RNA virus with a large RNA genome. Although not much is known about the specific mechanisms underlying severe disease in COVID-19, there are indications that the virus is capable of inducing an excessive immune reaction in the host, with highly activated but decreased numbers of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells detected in the peripheral blood of COVID-19 patients (Xu 2020). Preliminary reports into the pathophysiology of SARS-CoV-2 have further indicated the observed decrease in human angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) activity may play a role in causing the rapid deterioration of patient lung function (Tolouian 2020; van de Veerdonk 2020). ACE2 is a protein which functions as the receptor facilitating entry of SARS-CoV-2 into the host cell, and is most abundant on type II alveolar cells in the lungs. Under physiological conditions, ACE2 hydrolyzes the active bradykinin metabolite des-Arg9 bradykinin (DABK), which prevents fluid extravasation and leukocyte recruitment to the lung. The accumulation of DABK is postulated to increase permeability of pulmonary capillaries leading to angioedema and ultimately respiratory failure, which can have fatal consequences for COVID-19 patients.

Description of the intervention
Convalescent plasma, convalescent serum and hyperimmune immunoglobulin prepared from convalescent plasma, are interventions which have historically been used to treat conditions when no vaccine or pharmacological interventions are available. Diphtheria, pneumococcal pneumonia, hepatitis A and B, mumps, polio, measles and rabies are conditions where convalescent plasma has successfully been applied (Eibl 2008).

Convalescent plasma has been shown to potentially have clinical benefit for patients with influenza and SARS in a recent systematic review of the literature (Mair-Jenkins 2015). This systematic review included observational studies and RCTs investigating the use of convalescent plasma, serum or hyperimmune immunoglobulin for treating severe acute respiratory infections of laboratory-confirmed or suspected viral etiology, and included investigations with patients of any age and sex. Control interventions consisted of sham therapy, no therapy and placebo. The authors concluded that, although included studies were generally small and of low quality, with a moderate to high risk of bias, the use of convalescent plasma may reduce mortality and appears safe (Mair-Jenkins 2015). The authors also suggests the effectiveness of convalescent plasma in reducing hospital length of stay is dependent on early administration of the therapy, and use as prophylaxis is more likely to be beneficial than treating severe disease. However, the optimal timing of convalescent plasma therapy is unknown. The optimal dosage of convalescent plasma therapy is also unknown.

The currently available evidence regarding the effect of convalescent plasma or hyperimmune immunoglobulin for treating severe acute respiratory infections can be considered conflicting. Especially studies investigating effectiveness of convalescent plasma for influenza have been contradictory, with some randomized controlled trials showing effectiveness (Hung 2013), and other trials not being able to show benefit of convalescent plasma over placebo (Beigel 2019; Beigel 2017; Davey 2019).

And, although convalescent plasma is generally regarded to be a safe and well-tolerated therapy, side effects can occur. Limited information is available about specific side effects of convalescent plasma, but chills and a possible case of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) have been reported (Chun 2016). Plasma transfusions are further known to carry the risk of transfusion transmitted infections, allergic transfusion reactions and transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) Especially TACO and TRALI are important to consider, because the COVID-19 patients with poor prognosis and high co-morbidity burden who might be eligible for experimental treatment with convalescent plasma therapy, are at an increased risk of these adverse effects.

How the intervention might work
Convalescent plasma contains pathogen-specific neutralizing immunoglobulins which can neutralize viral particles, and treatment with convalescent plasma or hyperimmune immunoglobulins confers passive immunity to patients who receive it. The duration of conferred protection can differ depending on the timing of administration, it ranging from weeks to months after treatment (Casadevall 2020).

By neutralizing SARS-CoV-2 particles, early treatment with convalescent plasma is postulated to increase the patient’s own capacity to clear the initial inoculum (Casadevall 2020). This could lead to a reduction in mortality and less progression of hospitalized patients to the ICU. Convalescent plasma is further hypothesized to reduce the length of ICU stay in critically ill patients, thus helping lift pressure from global healthcare systems and increasing ICU capacity.

Preliminary evidence in humans and rhesus macaques has shown that reinfection with SARS-CoV-2 is not likely, with most (but not all) patients who recovered from COVID-19 producing sufficient amounts of neutralizing antibodies to protect against reinfection (Bao 2020; Wu 2020a). This implies convalescent plasma from patients following SARS-CoV-2 infection is capable of conferring passive immunity. A recently reported case series also indicated sufficient neutralizing antibody titers in convalescent plasma to neutralize SARS-CoV-2 in 5 COVID-19 patients, who all recovered after treatment (Shen 2020). It is important to note, however, that there are indications that the severity of infection has an impact on antibody titers, with less severe disease leading to lower neutralizing antibody response (Amanna 2007). And, research in other coronavirus species has shown that immunity may not be long-lasting, with 2-3 years of protection estimated from work with SARS and MERS (Payne 2016; Mo 2006).

Why it is important to do this review
There is a clear, urgent medical need for more information to guide clinical decision-making for COVID-19 patients. Pharmacological interventions have not yet proven to be effective, and current treatment consists of supportive care with oxygen supply in mild cases and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation in severe cases. A vaccine could aid in inducing immunity in the population and preventing transmission to those who are at risk for severe disease, but no vaccine is currently available, although multiple candidate vaccines are in development. Until these vaccines are available and distributed, convalescent plasma is a potentially life-saving addition to the current treatment regimen for critically ill COVID-19 patients. Convalescent plasma, and hyperimmune immunoglobulin to a certain extent, can be prepared and made rapidly available by blood banks and hospitals when enough potential donors have recovered from the infection, using readily available materials and methods (Bloch 2020). However, its safety and efficacy are not well characterised yet, and there are costs associated with pursuing the use of convalescent plasma for treatment of COVID-19.

A multitude of clinical trials investigating the safety and effectiveness of convalescent plasma or hyperimmune immunoglobulins have been announced, and their results will need to be interpreted with care. Thus, there needs to be a thorough understanding of the current body of evidence regarding the use of convalescent plasma for people with COVID-19, and an extensive review of the available literature is required.

Objectives
To assess whether convalescent plasma or hyperimmune immunoglobulinsconvalescent plasma transfusion is beneficial and safe in the treatment of people with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).

question.value: We will conduct a systematic rapid review. We structured the methods according to the guidance of the Cochrane Rapid Reviews Methods Group.

question.value:
Criteria for considering studies for this review

Types of studies
To assess the benefits and safety of convalescent plasma for the therapy of COVID-19 we plan to include randomised controlled trials (RCTs) only, as such trials, if performed appropriately, currently give the best evidence for experimental therapies in highly controlled therapeutic settings. When RCT data are available, we will use the common methods recommended by the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Higgins 2019), as specified in the following description of the methods.

If there is insufficient evidence (very low-quality evidence or no evidence) available from RCTs to answer this review's questions we will include prospective controlled non-randomised studies of interventions (NRSIs), including quasi-randomised controlled trials (e.g. assignment to treatment by alternation or by date of birth), controlled before-and-after (CBA) studies, and interrupted time series (ITS) studies. In that case, we will use the methods proposed in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions for the inclusion of NRSIs in systematic reviews (Reeves 2017).

If there is insufficient evidence (very low-quality evidence or no evidence) available from RCTs and NRSIs we will include prospective observational studies with a control group and will adapt the methods for the inclusion of NRSIs in systematic reviews as specified by the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions as well (Reeves 2017).

If there is no evidence from RCTs, NRSIs, and prospective observational studies, we will include prospective non-comparative study designs (e.g. case series). In that case, we will follow the common suggestions specified in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Higgins 2019), as far as possible, and apply methodology outlined in the following protocol sections. We will only consider studies including 1 or more participants with COVID-19.

We will include full-text publications, abstract publications, and results published in study registries, if sufficient information is available on study design, characteristics of participants, interventions and outcomes. There will be no limitation with respect to the length of follow-up.

Types of participants: 
We will include individuals with a confirmed diagnosis of COVID-19, with no age, gender or ethnicity restrictions.

We will exclude trials including populations with other coronavirus diseases (SARS or MERS). We will also exclude trials including populations with mixed virus diseases (e.g. influenza), unless the trial authors provide subgroup data for people with COVID-19. 

Types of interventions:
We will include the following main comparison for studies with a control arm.

Convalescent plasma versus standard care or placebo
Convalescent plasma therapy versus control treatment, for example, drug treatments (e.g. but not limited to hydroxychloroquine, remdesivir ). Cointerventions will be allowed, but must be comparable between intervention groups
Convalescent plasma therapy versus hyperimmune globulin
Hyperimmune globulin versus standard care or placebo
Hyperimmune globulin versus control treatment, for example, drug treatments (e.g. but not limited to hydroxychloroquine, remdesivir). Cointerventions will be allowed, but must be comparable between intervention groups
We are not expecting a large body of evidence as informed by scoping of this topic area. However, if we encounter an unexpected larger volume, we may be decide during conduct to limit the review to a subset of comparisons, for feasibility.

Types of outcome measures
We will evaluate core outcomes as pre-defined by the Core Outcome Measures in Effectiveness Trials Initiative for Covid-19 patients (COMET 2020).
Primary outcomes: 
All-cause mortality at hospital discharge
Time to death

Secondary outcomes: 
Number of participants with grade 3 and grade 4 adverse events, including potential relationship between intervention and adverse reaction (e.g. transfusion‐related acute lung injury (TRALI), transfusion‐transmitted infection, transfusion‐associated circulatory overload (TACO), transfusion‐associated dyspnoea (TAD), acute transfusion reactions)
Number of participants with serious adverse events
Improvement of clinical symptoms, assessed through need for respiratory support at up to 7 days; 8 to 15 days; 16 to 30 days
Oxygen by mask or nasal prongs
Oxygen by NIV or high flow
Intubation and mechanical ventilation
Mechanical ventilation
ECMO.
If doable resources permit, we will also include the following secondary outcomes: 

30-day and 90-day mortality
Admission on the intensive care unit
Length of stay on the intensive care unit
Time to discharge from hospital
Timing of outcome measurement
For time-to-event outcomes, such as mortality, discharge from hospital, and improvement of clinical symptoms, we will include outcome measures representing the longest follow-up time available.

All other outcome categories will be included for the observational periods which were reported in the study publications. We will include those adverse events occurring during active treatment as well as long-term adverse events. If sufficient data are available, we will group the measurement time points of eligible outcomes, for example, adverse events and serious adverse events, into those measured directly after treatment (up to 7 days after treatment), medium-term outcomes (15 days after treatment) and longer-term outcomes (over 30 days after treatment).

Search methods for identification of studies
We will adapt search strategies from the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Lefebvre 2019).  We will search for studies in all languages in order to limit language bias. However, we will prioritise articles in languages that our review team can accommodate (these are: English, Dutch, German, French, Italian, Malay, Spanish). We will not seek for translators via Cochrane Task Exchange for this version of the review. We will tag all references in additional languages as "awaiting classification" and will seek for translators via Cochrane Task Exchange in an update of this review.  

Electronic searches
Search strategies for electronic databases will be adapted from those suggested in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Lefebvre 2019). In this emerging field, we expect that at least the abstract will be in English. In case of studies published in other languages, we will involve Cochrane Task Exchange to identify people within Cochrane to translate these studies.

As publication bias might influence all subsequent analyses and conclusions, we will search all potential relevant trial registries in detail to detect ongoing as well as completed studies, but not yet published studies. Nowadays, it is mandatory to provide results at least in the study registry. In case results are not published elsewhere, we will extract and analyse these data.

We will search the following databases and sources, from 2019 onwards:

Databases of medical literature:
WHO COVID-19 Global Research Database (https://search.bvsalud.org/global-research-on-novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov/advanced/?lang=en), see file attached
MEDLINE (Ovid, 2019 to present), see file attached
Embase (Ovid, 2019 to present), see file attached
PubMed (for epublications ahead of print only), see file attached
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention COVID-19 Research Article Database (downloaded April 13, 2020), see file attached

Study registries and registry platforms to identify ongoing studies and results of completed studies:
Cochrane COVID-19 Study Register (https://covid-19.cochrane.org/), see file attached
ClinicalTrials.gov - Covid-19 Subset, see file attached
WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (ICTRP) - Covid-19 Subset, see file attached

Data collection
Selection of studies
Two review authors will independently screen the results of the search strategies for eligibility for this review by reading the abstracts using Covidence software (Covidence 2016). We will code the abstracts as either 'retrieve' or 'do not retrieve'. In the case of disagreement or if it is unclear whether we should retrieve the abstract or not, we will obtain the full-text publication for further discussion. Two review authors will assess the full-text articles of selected studies. If the two review authors are unable to reach a consensus, we will consult a third review author to reach a final decision Lefebvre 2019.

We will document the study selection process in a flow chart, as recommended in the PRISMA statement (Moher 2009), and will show the total numbers of retrieved references and the numbers of included and excluded studies. We will list all articles that we excluded after full-text assessment and their reasons for exclusion in a 'Characteristics of excluded studies' table.

Data extraction and management
All extractions and assessments will be performed by one author. A second author will verify the accuracy and (where applicable) the plausibility of extractions and assessment.

One review author will assess eligible studies obtained in the process of study selection (as described above) for methodological quality and risk of bias. 

One review author will extract data using a standardised data extraction form developed in Covidence (Covidence). Data extraction will be conducted according to the guidelines proposed by Cochrane. If the review authors are unable to reach a consensus, we will consult a third review author. 

We will collate multiple reports of one study so that the study, and not the report, is the unit of analysis.

We will extract the following information.

General information: author, title, source, publication date, country, language, duplicate publications
Quality assessment: (as specified in the Assessment of risk of bias in included studies section)
Study characteristics: trial design, setting and dates, source of participants, inclusion/exclusion criteria, comparability of groups, treatment cross-overs, compliance with assigned treatment, length of follow-up
Participant characteristics: age, gender, ethnicity, number of participants recruited/allocated/evaluated, disease, severity of disease, additional diagnoses, previous treatments (e.g. experimental drug therapies, oxygen therapy, ventilation)
Interventions: convalescent plasma therapy or hyperimmune globulin therapy, concomitant therapy, duration of follow-up
For studies including a control group: comparator (type)
Outcomes: 
Primary outcomes:
All-cause mortality at hospital discharge
Time to death
Secondary outcomes:
Number of participants with grade 3 and grade 4 adverse events, including potential relationship between intervention and adverse reaction (e.g. transfusion‐related acute lung injury (TRALI), transfusion‐transmitted infection, transfusion‐associated circulatory overload (TACO), transfusion‐associated dyspnoea (TAD), acute transfusion reactions)
Number of participants with serious adverse events
Improvement of clinical symptoms, assessed through need for respiratory support at up to 7 days; 8 to 15 days; 16 to 30 days
30-day and 90-day mortality
Admission on the intensive care unit
Length of stay on the intensive care unit
Time to discharge from hospital

Assessment of risk of bias in included studies
Randomised controlled trials
We will use the Risk of Bias 2.0 (RoB 2) tool to analyse the risk of bias in the underlying study results (Sterne 2019). Of interest for this review is the effect of the assignment to the intervention (the ITT effect) and we will perform all assessments with RoB 2 on this effect. The outcomes that will be addressed are those specified for inclusion in the GRADE Summary of Findings tables. Accordingly, the outcomes will be prioritised based on close communication with patient representatives.

One review author will assess the risk of bias for each study result. A second author will verify the accuracy and the plausibility. In case discrepancies among their judgements arise or they are unable to reach consensus, we will consult a third review author to reach a final decision. We will assess the following types of bias as outlined in Chapter 8 of the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Higgins 2019).

Bias arising from the randomisation process.
Bias due to deviations from the intended interventions.
Bias due to missing outcome data.
Bias in measurement of the outcome.
Bias in selection of the reported result.
To address these types of bias we will used the signalling questions recommended in RoB 2 and make a judgement using the following options:

'yes': if there is firm evidence that the question is fulfilled in the study (i.e. the study is at low or high risk of bias for the given the direction of the question)
'probably yes': a judgement has been made that the question is fulfilled in the study (i.e. the study is at low or high risk of bias given the direction of the question).
'no': if there is firm evidence that the question is unfilled in the study (i.e. the study is at low or high risk of bias for the given the direction of the question)
'probably no': a judgement has been made that the question is unfilled in the study (i.e. the study is at low or high risk of bias given the direction of the question)
'no information' if the study report does not provide sufficient information to allow any judgement
We will use the algorithms proposed by RoB 2 to assigns each domain one of the following levels of bias:

Low risk of bias
Some concerns
High risk of bias
Subsequently we will derive a risk of bias rating for each prespecified outcome in each study in accordance with the following suggestions:

'Low risk of bias': The trial is judged to be at low risk of bias for all domains for this result
'Some concerns': The trial is judged to raise some concerns in at least one domain for this result, but not to be at high risk of bias for any domain
'High risk of bias': The trial is judged to be at high risk of bias in at least one domain for the result OR the trial is judged to have some concerns for multiple domains in a way that substantially lowers confidence in the results.
Non-randomised controlled studies
As reported in the Types of studies section, we will include non-randomised studies if there is insufficient evidence from RCTs.

One review author will assess eligible studies for methodological quality and risk of bias (using the Risk Of Bias in Non-randomised Studies - of Interventions (ROBINS-I) tool) (Sterne 2019). A second author will verify the accuracy and the plausibility. The quality assessment strongly depends upon information on the design, conduct and analysis of the trial. The two review authors will resolve any disagreements regarding the quality assessments by consulting a third review author until they reach a consensus.

We will assess the following domains of bias.

Bias due to confounding
Bias in selection of participants into the study
Bias in classification of interventions
Bias due to deviations from intended interventions
Bias due to missing data
Bias in measurement of outcomes
Bias in selection of the reported result
For every criterion we will make a judgement using one of five response options.

Yes
Probably yes
Probably no
No
No information
Non-controlled prospectively planned trials
As specified in the Types of studies section we will only include non-controlled prospective studies if we do not identify any controlled studies.

One review author will assess eligible studies for methodological quality and risk of bias (using the 'Risk of bias' assessment criteria for observational studies tool provided by the Cochrane Childhood Cancer Group (seeTable 1). A second author will verify the accuracy and the plausibility. Any 'Risk of bias' judgements will be performed and presented per outcome per study.

The quality assessment strongly depends upon information on the design, conduct and analysis of the trial. The two review authors will resolve any disagreements regarding the quality assessments by discussion, in case they do not reach a consensus they will consult a third review author.

We will assess the following domains of bias.

Internal validity
Unrepresentative study group (selection bias)
Incomplete outcome assessment/follow‐up (attrition bias)
Outcome assessors unblinded to investigated determinant (detection bias)
Important prognostic factors or follow‐up not taken adequately into account (confounding)
External validity
Poorly defined study group (reporting bias)
Poorly defined follow‐up (reporting bias)
Poorly defined outcome (reporting bias)
Poorly defined risk estimates (analyses)
For every criterion, we will make a judgement using one of three response options.

High risk of bias
Low risk of bias
Unclear risk of bias

question.value: not applicable

Randomised controlled trials
For continuous outcomes, we will record the mean, standard deviation and total number of participants in both the treatment and control groups. For dichotomous outcomes, we will record the number of events and total number of participants in both the treatment and control groups.
For continuous outcomes using the same scale we will perform analyses using the mean difference (MD) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs). For continuous outcomes measured with different scales we will perform analyses using the standardised mean difference (SMD).

If available, we will extract and report hazard ratios (HRs) for time-to-event outcomes (overall survival, progression-free survival). If HRs are not available, we will make every effort to estimate as accurately as possible the HR using the available data and a purpose-built method based on the Parmar and Tierney approach (Parmar 1998; Tierney 2007) in an update of this review. If sufficient studies provide HRs, we will use HRs rather than RRs or MDs in a meta-analysis.
For dichotomous outcomes, we will report the pooled risk ratio (RR) with a 95% CI (Deeks 2019). If the number of observed events is small (less than 5% of sample per group), and if trials had balanced treatment groups, we plan to report the Peto odds ratio (OR) with 95% CI (Deeks 2019).
For cluster-randomised trials, we will extract and report direct estimates of the effect measure (e.g. RR with a 95% CI) from an analysis that accounts for the clustered design. We will obtain statistical advice to ensure the analysis is appropriate. If appropriate analyses are not available, we will make every effort to approximate the analysis following the recommendations in Chapter 6 of the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Higgins 2019b) in an update of this review.

Non-randomised controlled studies
For dichotomous outcomes, if available we plan to extract and report the RR with a 95% CI from statistical analyses adjusting for baseline differences (such as Poisson regressions or logistic regressions) or the ratio of RRs (i.e. the RR postintervention/risk ratio pre-intervention).

For continuous variables, if available, we plan to extract and report the absolute change from a statistical analysis adjusting for baseline differences (such as regression models, mixed models or hierarchical models), or the relative change adjusted for baseline differences in the outcome measures (i.e. the absolute postintervention difference between the intervention and control groups, as well as the absolute pre-intervention difference between the intervention and control groups/the postintervention level in the control group) (European (accessed 29 June 2018)).

Uncontrolled studies
For uncontrolled studies we will not carry out an analysis using quantitative data from indirect controls, as we are aware of the difficulties of indirect comparisons of participant groups with varying baseline characteristics, especially in the absence of individual patient data. Because authors of one-arm, non-comparative studies, often discuss their findings using information from other intervention and observational studies as implicit controls, we will discuss our findings extensively in the context of what is known about the outcome of 'comparable' patients receiving other experimental treatments but not convalescent plasma therapy or hyperimmune globulin therapy. We will not combine the data but provide information from individual studies within tables.

Unit of analysis issues
Studies with multiple treatment groups
As recommended in Chapter 6 of the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Higgins 2019b), for studies with multiple treatment groups we will combine arms as long as they can be regarded as subtypes of the same intervention.

When arms can not be pooled this way, we will compare each arm with the common comparator separately. For pair-wise meta-analysis, we will split the ‘shared’ group into two or more groups with smaller sample size, and include two or more (reasonably independent) comparisons. For this purpose, for dichotomous outcomes, both the number of events and the total number of patients will be divided up, and for continuous outcomes, the total number of participants will be divided up with unchanged means and SDs.

not applicable

Assessment of heterogeneity
We will assess heterogeneity of treatment effects between trials using a Chi2 test with a significance level at P < 0.1. We will use the I2 statistic to quantify possible heterogeneity (I2 statistic > 30% to signify moderate heterogeneity, I2 statistic > 75% to signify considerable heterogeneity; Deeks 2019). If heterogeneity is above 80%, we will explore potential causes through sensitivity and subgroup analyses. If we cannot find a reason for heterogeneity, we will not perform a meta-analysis, but will comment on results from all studies and present these in tables.

 

Assessment of reporting biases
As mentioned above, we will search trial registries to identify completed trials which have not been published elsewhere, to minimise or determine publication bias.

In an update of this review, we intend to explore potential publication bias by generating a funnel plot and statistically testing this by conducting a linear regression test (Sterne 2019) for meta-analyses involving at least 10 trials. We will consider P < 0.1 as significant for this test.

Data synthesis
If the clinical and methodological characteristics of individual studies are sufficiently homogeneous, we will pool the data in meta-analysis. We will perform analyses according to the recommendations of the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Deeks 2019). We will not conduct meta-analyses that involve both RCTs and non-RCTs. We will conduct separate meta-analyses for each comparison.

We will use the Review Manager 5 software for analyses (Review Manager 5 (RevMan 5)). One review author will enter the data into the software, and a second review author will check the data for accuracy.

We will use the random-effects model for all analyses as we anticipate that true effects will be related but will not be the same for included studies. If we cannot perform a meta-analysis, we will comment on the results as a narrative with the results from all studies presented in tables.

For RCTs, when meta-analysis is feasible, we will use the random-effects model for pooling the data. For binary outcomes, we will base the estimation of the between-study variance using the Mantel-Haenszel method. We will use the inverse variance method for continuous outcomes, outcomes that include data from cluster-RCTs, or outcomes where HRs are available. If heterogeneity is found to be above 80%, and we identify a cause for the heterogeneity, we will explore this with subgroup analyses. If we cannot find a cause for the heterogeneity then we will not perform a meta-analysis, but comment on the results as a narrative with the results from all studies presented in tables.

If a meta-analysis is feasible for non-RCTs, controlled before-and-after studies, interrupted time series studies, and cohort studies, we will analyse the different types of studies separately. We will only analyse outcomes with adjusted effect estimates if these are adjusted for the same factors using the inverse-variance method as recommended in Chapter 24 of the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Reeves 2017).

We will not meta-analyse data from uncontrolled trials, as there might be no additional benefit in meta-analysing data without a control group. In the case of uncontrolled trials, we will report outcome data of each included trial within tables.

If data do not allow quantitative assessment, we will present outcome data individually per study within tables.

Summary of findings and assessment of the certainty of the evidence
We will use the GRADE approach to assess the quality of the evidence for our primary outcomes. We will use GRADEpro Guideline Development Tool (GDT) software to create a 'Summary of findings' table (GRADEpro GDT 2015), as suggested in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Schünemann 2019).

q21.value:
Chapter 6 of the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions suggests a number of potential sources for missing data (Higgins 2019b), which we will need to take into account: at study level, at outcome level and at summary data level. In the first instance, it is of the utmost importance to differentiate between data 'missing at random' and 'not missing at random'.

If data are missing, we will request these data from the principal investigators in an update of this review. If, after this, data are still missing, we will have to make explicit assumptions of any methods the included studies used. For example, we will assume that the data were missing at random or we will assume that missing values had a particular value, such as a poor outcome.
